Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Development of Cassandra, A General, Efficient and Parallel Monte Carlo Multiscale Modeling Software Platform for Materials Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The properties of materials are the result of the interactions between the atoms that make up these materials. These properties can now be predicted with great accuracy, even for materials that have not yet existed in nature, by using advanced computational methods to study how the constituent atoms of the materials interact with one another and their environment. This field relies upon the existence of sophisticated software packages that enable researchers to conduct these simulations. There are two general approaches for simulating bulk materials: molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo, each of which is appropriate for certain problems. There are many molecular dynamics software packages available but almost no general purpose Monte Carlo codes. This project seeks to develop an efficient, general-purpose open source Monte Carlo code called Cassandra.

To do this, the academic Monte Carlo code developed in the PI's group will be extended and enhanced. The code will be capable of simulating any type of molecule in bulk and heterogeneous environments. The code will contain a wide range of advanced features, making it useful for a range of problems. By providing a general purpose code to the research community and establishing a mechanism whereby users can add their own features and extend the code, this project will have a broad impact on the research community. It will enable non-experts to use Monte Carlo simulations to study new problems. It will enable experienced molecular modelers to utilize and contribute features to a single optimized and validated code, thereby alleviating the time and expense associated with developing specialized codes for individual applications. Because the code will be used in teaching and workshops, materials will be made available to educators to use the code in the classroom when teaching courses such as thermodynamics, molecular modeling and statistical mechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is possible to predict the properties of materials by calculating the physical interactions between all the atoms present, but this is a hard problem. This is because there are so many atoms to consider in any macroscopic material, and because the interactions between atoms are complex. Given the huge increases in computer power, it is becoming possible to perform such calculations but a key limitation has been the software available to perform these simulations. There have been great advances in developing software to perform sub-classes of the calculations required (these methods are known as “molecular dynamics” and “quantum mechanics” methods) but the software needed to carry out another important type of simulation (so-called “Monte Carlo” calculations) has been lacking. The goal of this project was to develop a general purpose, freely available open source software package that can perform atomistic Monte Carlo simulations on materials. The package that was developed as part of this project is called “Cassandra”. The latest methods were incorporated into Cassandra to make the simulations fast. Tools were developed to help make running the calculations easier, and extensive documentation and webpage support documents were created to assist users. Three special educational workshops were held to teach users about the basics of Monte Carlo and how to use Cassandra. Cassandra can now be used to perform a wide range of important calculations. For example, it has been used to help design new battery electrolytes, to predict how to more effectively perform chemical separations and to understand how pollutants partition between water and tissue. Because the software is so flexible, it can be applied to an almost limitless number of systems where thermodynamic properties and material structure are important.

The software package has been downloaded by almost 700 research groups around the world. A recent independent study found that the code gave correct results and that it was fast. Several research groups are now working to add additional features to the open source package, which will allow Cassandra to grow in scope and robustness. Cassandra has been used in courses at several universities and several publications have already been published using Cassandra. In the near future, Cassandra will be integrated with a molecular modeling framework that includes several other codes, making it easier to run calculations using multiple pieces of software.
